publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: _WHat happineſs waits on the life at Court,
What dear content, greatneſs, delight & eaſe?
What ever-ſpringing hopes, what tides of honour,
That raiſe their fortunes to the height of wiſhes?
What can be more in man, what more in nature,
Then to be great and fear'd? A Courtier,
A noble Courtier, 'Tis a name that drawes
Wonder, and dutie, from all eyes and knees.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And ſo your Worſhips land within the walls,
Where you ſhall have it all inclos'd and ſure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace knave; dull creature, bred of ſweate and ſmoke,
Theſe myſteries are far above thy faith:
But thou ſhalt ſee—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And then I ſhall believe;
Your faire revenues, turn'd into faire ſuites,
I ſhall believe your Tenants bruis'd and rent
Under the weight of Coaches, all your ſtate
Drawn through the ſtreets in triumph, ſuits for places
Plied with a mine of gold, and being got
Fed with a great ſtreame, I ſhall believe all this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You ſhall believe, and know me glorious.
Cozin good day and health. Enter Cozen.

sp.speaker: Couzen.
sp.l: The ſame to you Sir,
And more, without my wiſhes, could you know
What calm content dwels in a private houſe:
Yet looke into your ſelfe, retire: this place
Of promiſes, and proteſtations, fits
Minds only bent to ruine, you ſhould know this,
You have their language perfect, you have tutors
I doe not doubt ſufficient: but beware.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are merry Couzin:

sp.speaker: C●zen.
sp.l: Yet your patience,
You ſhall learn that too, but not like it ſelfe
Where it is held a vertue; tell me Sir,
Have you caſt up your ſtate, rated your land,
And finde it able to endure the change
Of time and faſhion? is it alwayes harveſt?
Alwayes vintage? have you ſhips at Sea
To bring you gold, and ſtone from rich Peru
Monthly returning treaſure? doth the King
Open his large Exchequer to your hands
And bid you be a great man? can your wife
Coyne off her beauty? or the weeke allow
Suites to each day? and know no ebb in honour?
If theſe be poſſible, and can hold out,
Then be a Courtier ſtill, and ſtill be waſting,

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Cozen, pray give me leave:

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I could requite your gall, and in a ſtraine
As bitter, and as full of Rubarb, preacht
Againſt your Countrey life, but 'tis below me
And only ſubject to my pitty, know
The eminent court, to them that can be wiſe,
And faſten on her bleſſings, is a ſunne
That drawes men up from courſe and earthly being,
I meane theſe men of merit that have power
And reaſon to make good her benefits,
Learns them a manly boldneſſe, gives their tongues
Sweetneſſe of language, makes them apt to pleaſe;
Files of all rudeneſſe, and uncivill haviour,
Shews them as neat in carriage as in cloaths;
Cozen have you ever ſeen the Court?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: No Sir,
Nor am I yet in travaile with that longing.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O the ſtate, and greatneſſe of that place
Where men are found
Only to give the firſt creation glory!
Thoſe are the models of the ancient world
Left like the Roman ſtatues to ſtir up
Our following hopes, the place it ſelfe puts on
The brow of Majeſtie, and flings her luſtre
Like the aire newly lightned, forme, and order,
Are only there themſelues, unforc't, and ſound,
As they were firſt created to this place.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: You nobly came, but wil goe from thence baſe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Twas very pretty, and a good conceite;
You have a wit good Cozen, I do joy in't,
Keep it for Court: but to my ſelfe againe,
When I have view'd theſe pieces, turn'd theſe eyes,
And with ſome taſte of ſuperſtition,
Lookt on the wealth of Nature, the faire dames,
Beauties, that lights the Court, and makes it ſhew
Like a faire heaven, in a froſty night:
And mongſt theſe mine, not pooreſt, 'tis for tongues
Of bleſſed Poets, ſuch as Orpheus was,
To give their worth and praiſes; O deare Cozen:
You have a wife, and faire, bring her hither,
Let her not live to be the Miſtris of a Farmers heir
And be confined ever to a ſerge,
Farre courſer then my horſe-cloath.
Let her have Velvets, Tiffinies, Jewels, Pearls,
A Coach, an Uſher, and her two Lacquies,
And I will ſend my Wife to give her rules,
And reade the rudiments of Court to her.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Sir I had rather ſend her to Virginia
To help to propagate the Engliſh nation. Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Sirra, how ſlept your Miſtris, and what viſitants
Are to pay ſervice?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir as I came out,
Two Counts were newly entered.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This is greatneſſe,
But few ſuch ſervants waite a Countrey beauty.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: They are the more to thank their modeſty,
God keep my wife, and all my Iſſue female
From ſuch upriſings. Enter a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What? my learned Doctor?
You will be welcome, give her health and youth
And I will give you gold. Exit Doctor.
Cozen, how ſavours this? is it not ſweet?
And very great, taſts it not of Nobleneſſe?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Faith Sir my pallat is too dull and lazie
I cannot taſte it, 'tis not for my reliſh,
But be ſo ſtill.
Since your own miſery muſt firſt reclaime ye,
To which I leave you Sir,
If you will yet be happy, leave the humour
And baſe ſubjection to your Wife, be wiſe,
And let her know with ſpeed you are her husband,
I ſhall be glad to heare it.
My horſe is ſent for. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Even ſuch another countrey thing as this
Was I, ſuch a piece of durt, ſo heavy,
So provident to heap up ignorance,
And be an aſſe: ſuch muſty cloaths wore I,
So old and threed-bare: I do yet remember
Divers young Gallants lighting at my gate,
To ſee my honoured wife, have offered pence,
And bid me walk their horſes, ſuch a ſlave
Was I in ſhew then: but my eyes are open'd.
Many ſweet morrows to my worthy Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and aptly given, as much for you,
But to my preſent buſineſſe, which is money—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Lady I have none left.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I hope you dare not ſay ſo, nor imagin ſo baſe and lowe,
A thought: I have none left.
Are theſe words fitting for a man of worth,
And one of your full credite? Do you know
The place you live in? me, and what I labour
For, you? and your advancement?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes my deareſt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And do you pop me off with this ſlight anſwer,
In troth I have none left? in troth you muſt have;
Nay ſtare not, 'tis moſt true, ſend ſpeedily
To all that love you, let your people flye
Like thunder through the Citie,
And not return under five thouſand crownes.
Try all, take all, let not a wealthy merchant be untempted
Or any that hath the name of money,
Take up at any uſe, give band, or land,
Or mighty ſtatutes able by their ſtrength
To tye up Sampſon were he now alive,
There muſt be money gotten; for be perſwaded,
If we fall now, or be but ſeen to ſhrinke,
Under our faire beginnings, 'tis our ruine,
And then good-night to all, (but our diſgrace)
Farewell the hope of comming happineſſe,
And all the aimes we levied at ſo long.
Are ye not mov'd at this? no ſenſe of want,
Towards your ſelfe yet breeding? be old,
And common; jaded to the eyes
Of groomes, and pages, chamber-maides, and garders,
And when you have done, put your poor houſe in order
And hang your ſelfe, for ſuch muſt be the end
Of him that willingly forſakes his hopes
And hath a joy to tumble to his ruine.
All that I ſay is certaine, if ye faile
Do not impute me with it, I am cleare.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now heaven forbid I ſhould do wrong to you
My deareſt Wife, and Madam; yet give leave
To your poore creature to unfold himſelfe.
You know my debts are many more then meanes,
My bands not taken in, my friends at home
Drawn dry with theſe expences, my poore Tenants
More full of want then we, then what new courſe
Can I beget to raiſe thoſe crowns by? ſpeake,
And I ſhall execute.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray tell me true,
Have you not land in the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pardon me, I had forgot it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt remember it,
There is no remedy, this land muſt be
In Paris ere to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It ſhall, let me conſider, ſome 300. acres
Will ſerve the turne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill furniſh at all points,
Now you ſpeak like your ſelfe, and know like him,
That meanes to be man, ſuſpect no leſſe
For the return will give ye five for one,
You ſhall be great to morrow, I have ſaid it.
Farewell, and ſee this buſineſſe be a-foote
With expedition. Exit Wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Health, all joy, and honour
Waite on my lovely wife. What? Jaques, Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir did you call?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I did ſo, hie the Iaques.
Downe to the Bancke, and there to ſome good Merchant
(Conceive me well good Iaques, and be private)
Offer 300. acres of my land:
Say it is choiſe, and fertile, aske upon it
Five thouſand Crowns, this is the buſineſſe
I muſt employ thee in, be wiſe and ſpeedy.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir do not do this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Knave I muſt have money.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If you have money thus, your knave muſt tell ye
You will not have a foote of land left, be more warie
And more friend to your ſelfe, this honeſt land
Your Worſhip has diſcarded, has been true,
And done you loyall ſervice.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Gentle Iaques,
You have a merry wit, employ it well
About the buſineſſe you have now in hand.
When ye come backe, enquire me in the preſence,
If not, in the Tennis-Court, or at my houſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If this vaine hold, I know where to enquire ye.
Five thouſand crowns, this with good husbandry
May hold a month out, then 5000. more,
And more land a bleeding for't, as many more
And more land laid aſide. God and St. Dennis
Keep honeſt minded young men Bachellers.
'Tis ſtrange My M^r. ſhould be yet ſo young
A puppy, that he cannot ſee his fall
And got ſo neare the ſun. I'le to his Cozen
And once more tell him on't, if he faile,
Then to my mortgage, next unto my ſale. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Longovile, Bewford, and the Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Gentlemen, hold on diſcourſe a while,
I ſhall return with knowledge how, and where
We ſhall have beſt acceſſe unto my Miſtris
To Tender your devotions. Exit

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be it ſo:
Now to our firſt diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I prethee peace;
Thou canſt not be ſo bad, or make me know
Such things are living, doe not give thy ſelfe
So common and ſo idle, ſo open vile,
So great a wronger of thy worth, ſo low,
I cannot, nor I muſt not credite thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Now by this light I am a Whore-maſter,
An open and an excellent Whore-maſter,
And take a ſpeciall glory that I am ſo:
I thank my ſtars I am a Whore-maſter,
And ſuch a one as dare be known and ſeen,
And pointed at to be a noble wencher.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Do not let all eares heare this, harke ye Sir,
I am my ſelfe a Whore-maſter, I am
Believe it Sir (In private be it ſpoken)
I love a VVhore directly, moſt men are Wenchers,
And have profeſt the ſcience, few men
That looks upon ye now, but Whore-maſters,
Or have a full deſire to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: This is noble.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: It is without all queſtion, being private,
And held as needfull as intelligence,
But being once diſcover'd, blown abroad,
And known to common ſenſes, 'tis no more
Then geometrical rules in Carpenters
That only know ſome meaſure of an art,
But are not grounded: be no more deceived,
I have a conſcience to reclaim you, Sir.
Miſtake me not: I do not bid you leave your whore
Or leſſe to love her; forbid it
I ſhould be ſuch a villain to my friend,
Or ſo unnaturall: 'twas never harbor'd here,
Learn to be ſecret firſt, then ſtrike your Deere.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your faire inſtructions Monſieur I ſhall learn.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: And you ſhall have them: I deſire your care.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They are your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You muſt not love.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I meane a Lady, theres danger
Shee hath an Uſher and a Waiting-Gentlewoman,
A page, a Coach-man, theſe are feed, and fee'd
And yet for all that will be prating.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You underſtand me Sir, they will diſcover't,
And there is a loſſe of credite: table talke
Will be the end of this, or worſe, then that;
Will this be worthy of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Proceed good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Next leave your City Dame;
The beſt of that tribe are moſt meerly coy,
Or moſt extreamely fooliſh, both which vices
Are no great ſtirrers up, unleſſe in husbands
That owe this Cattle, fearing her thats coy
To be but ſeeming, her that's foole too forward.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the rareſt fellow, and the ſoundeſt
I meane in knowledge, that ere wore a Codpiece,
H'as found out that will paſſe all Italy,
All France and England, to their ſhames I ſpeake
And to the griefes of all their Gentlemen
The noble theory of luxury.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Your patience,
And I will lay before your eyes a courſe
That I my ſelfe found out, 'tis excellent,
Eaſy, and full of freedome.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O good Sir,
You rack me till I know it.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This it is,
When your deſire is up, your blood well heated
And apt for ſweet encounter, chuſe the night
And with the night your wench the ſtreets have ſtore,
There ſeize upon her, get her to your chamber,
Give her a cardecew, 'tis royall payment
When ye are dull, diſmiſſe her, no man knows
Nor ſhe her ſelfe, who hath encountred her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O but their faces.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Nere talke of faces:
The night allows her equall with a Dutches,
Imagination doth all think her faire,
And great, clapt in velvet, ſhe is ſo
Sir, I have tryed thoſe, and do find it certaine
It never failes me, 'tis but twelve nights ſince
My laſt experience.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O my meiching varlet, I'le fit ye as I live.
'Tis excellent, I'le be your Scholler Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are fairly welcome both: troth Gentlemen
You have been ſtrangers, I could chide you for't,
And taske ye with unkindneſs, what's the news?
The towne was never empty of ſome novelty;
Servant, what's your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Faith nothing.
I have not heard of any worth relating

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Nor I ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Then give me attention,
Monſieur Shattillion's mad.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Mad?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Mad as May-butter,
And which is more, mad for a wench.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange, and full of pitty.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: All that comes neare him
He thinks are come of purpoſe to betray him,
Being full of ſtrange conceite: the wench he loved
Stood very near the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Alas good Monſieur;
A' was a proper man, and faire demean'd,
A perſon worthy of a better temper.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: He is ſtrong opinion'd that the wench he loved
Remaines cloſe priſoner by the Kings command:
Fearing her title, when the poore grieved Gentlewoman
Follows him much lamenting, and much loving
In hope to make him well, he knows her not,
Nor any elſe that comes to viſite him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Let's walk in Gentlemen, and there diſcourſe
His further miſeries, you ſhall ſtay dinner,
In truth you muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We are your ſervants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Ther's no good to be done, no cure to be wrought
Upon my deſperate kinſman: I'le to horſe
And leave him to the fooles whip, miſery.
I ſhall recover twenty miles this night,
My horſe ſtands ready, I'le away with ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir, may I crave your name?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Yes Sir you may:
My name is Cleremon.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis wel, your faction?
What party knit you with?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I know no parties,
Nor no factions Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then weare this croſſe of white:
And where you ſee the like they are my friends,
Obſerve them well, the time is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Sir keep your croſſe, I'le wear none, ſure this fellow
Is much beſide himſelfe, grown mad.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: A word Sir;
You can pick nothing out of this, this croſſe
Is nothing but a croſſe, a very croſſe,
Plaine without ſpell or witch-craft, ſearch it,
You may ſuſpect, and well, there's poyſon in't,
Powder, or wild-fire, but 'tis nothing ſo.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I do beleeve you Sir, 'tis a plain croſſe.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then do your worſt, I care not, tell the King,
Let him know all this, as I am ſure he ſhall;
When you have ſpit your venome, then will I
Stand up a faithfull, and a loyall ſubject,
And ſo God ſave His Grace, this is no Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.p: He is March mad, farewell Monſieur. Exit Couzen.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Farewell;
I ſhall be here attending, 'tis my life
They aime at, there's no way to ſave it, well
Let 'em ſpread all their nets: they ſhall not draw me
Into any open Treaſon, I can ſee,
And can beware, I have my wits about me,
I thanke heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: There he goes,
That was the faireſt hope the French Court bred,
The worthieſt and the ſweeteſt temper'd ſpirit,
The trueſt, and the valianteſt, the beſt of judgment,
Till moſt unhappy I: ſever'd thoſe vertues
And turn'd his wit wild with a coy deniall,
Which heaven forgive me, and be pleas'd, O heaven
To give againe his ſenſes: that my love
May ſtrike off all my follies.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I Sis

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Your will with me ſweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir I come.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: From the dread ſoueraigne King, I know it Lady,
He is a gracious Prince, long may he live,
Pertaine you to his chamber?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No indeed Sir,
That place is not for women, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Yes, I do know you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Whats my name? pray you ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thats all one, I do know you and your buſineſſe,
You are diſcovered Lady, I am warie,
It ſtands upon my life; pray excuſe me,
The beſt man of this kingdome ſent you hither,
To dive into me, have I toucht you? ha?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd Sir, I come from your love,
That ſends you faire commends, and many kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Alas poore ſoule how does ſhe? is ſhe living?
Keepes ſhe her bed ſtill?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Still Sir, She is living,
And well, and ſhall do ſo.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Are ye in counſell?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No Sir, nor any of my ſex.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why ſo,
If you had been in counſell, you would know,
Her time to be but ſlender; ſhe muſt die.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I do believe it Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And suddainely,
She ſtands too neare a fortune.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo,
There is no jeſting with a Princes title,
Would we had both been borne of common parents
And liv'd a private and retired life,
In homely cottage, we had then enjoyed,
Our loves, and our embraces, theſe are things,
That cannot tend to treaſon—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I am wretched.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: O I pray as often for the King as any,
And with as true a hart, for's continuance,
And do moreover pray his heires may live;
And their faire iſſues, then as I am bound
For all the ſtates and commons, if theſe prayers
Be any wayes ambitious, I ſubmit,
And lay my head downe let 'em take it off;
You may informe againſt me, but withall
Remember my obedience to the crowne,
And ſervice to the ſtate.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Good Sir, I love yee.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then love the gratious King, and ſay with me

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Heaven ſave his grace.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is ſtrange—
A woman ſhould be ſent to undermine me,
And buz love into me to try my ſpirit;
Offer me kiſſes and enticing follies,
To make me open and betray my ſelfe;
It was a ſubtle and a dangerous plot,
And very ſoundly followed, farewell Lady,
Let me have equall hearing, and relate
I am an honeſt man. Heaven ſave the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'le never leave him, till by art or prayer
I have reſtorde his ſenſes, If I make
Him perfect man againe, he's mine ſtill, when
I here abjure all loves of other men. Exit

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir be perſwaded, go but back,
And tell him hee's undone, ſay nothing elſe;
And you ſhall ſee how things will worke upon't.

sp.speaker: Cozen.
sp.l: Not ſo good Jaques, I am held an aſſe
A countrey foole, good to converſe with durte
And eate courſe bread, weare the worſt wooll,
Know nothing but the high way to Paris,
And wouldſt thou have me bring theſe ſtaynes,
And imperfections to the riſing veiw
Of the right worſhipfull thy worthy Maſter?
They muſt be bright and ſhine, their cloathes
Soft velvet and the trojan purple
Like the Arabian gums, hung like the Sun,
Their golden beames on all ſides;
Such as theſe may come and know,
Thy Maſter, I am baſe and dare not ſpeake unto him,
Hee's above me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If ever you did love him, or his ſtate,
His name, his iſſue, or your ſelfe, go backe:
'Twill be an honeſt and a noble part
Worthy a kinsman, ſave 300 acres
From preſent execution; they have had ſentence,
And cannot be repriev'd, be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Have I not urg'd already all the reaſons,
I had to draw him from his will? his ruine?
But all in vaine, no counſell will prevaile,
Has fixt himſelfe, ther's no removing Jaques,
'Twil prove but breath and labour ſpent in vaine,
I'le to my horſe, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja..
sp.l: For Gods ſake Sir,
As ever you have hope of joy turne backe;
I'le be your ſlave for ever, do but go,
And I will lay ſuch faire directions to you
That if hee be not doting on his fall,
He ſhall recover ſight, and ſee his danger,
And ye ſhall tell him of his wives abuſes,
I feare, to foule againſt him; how ſhe plots,
With our young Mounſiers, to milke dry her husband,
And lay it on their backs, the next her pride,
Then what his debts are, and how infinite
The curſes of his tenants, this will worke
I'le pawne my life and head, he cryes away,
I'le to my houſe in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Come I'le go, and once more try him,
If he yeild not, ſo,
The next that tryes him ſhall be want and woe. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Riſe Jaques 'tis growne day,
The country life is beſt, where quietly
Free from the clamour of the troubled Court,
We may enjoy our own greene ſhadowed walkes,
And keepe a moderate diet without art.
Why did I leave my houſe and bring my wife,
To know the manner of this ſubtile place?
I would when firſt the luſt to fame an honour,
Poſſeſt me, I had met with any evill.
But that, had I been tyed to ſtay at home
And earn the bread for the whole family
With my own hand happy had I been.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir this is from your wonted courſe at home,
When did ye there keep ſuch inordinate hours?
Goe to bed late? ſtart thrice? and call on me?
Would you were from this place; our Countrey ſleepes,
Although they were but of that moderate length
That might maintain us in our daily worke.
Yet were they ſound and ſweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques, there we dreamt not of our wives, wee lay together;
And needed not; now at length my Cozins words,
So truly ment, mixt with thy timely prayers
So often urged, to keepe me at my home,
Condemne me quite.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Twas not your fathers courſe:
He liv'd and dy'd in Orleance, where he had
His Vines as fruitfull as experience
(Which is the art of husbandry) could make;
He had his preſſes for 'em, and his wines
Were held the beſt, and out-ſold other mens,
His corne and cattell ſerv'd the neighbour Townes
With plentifull proviſion, yet his thrift
Could miſſe one beaſt amongſt the heard,
He rul'd more where he liv'd, then ever you will here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis true, why ſhould my wife then 'gainſt my good,
Perſwade me to continue in this courſe?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why did you bring her hither at the firſt,
Before you warm'd her blood with new delights!
Our countrey ſports could have contented her,
When you firſt married her; a puppet-play
Pleas'd her as well as now the tilting doth.
She thought her ſelfe brave in a bugle chaine,
Where Orient pearle will ſcarce content her now.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sure Jaques, ſhe ſees ſomething for my good
More then I doe, ſhe oft will talk to me
Of offices, and that ſhe ſhortly hopes
By her acquaintance with the friends ſhe hath
To get a place ſhall many times outway
Our great expences, and if this be ſo—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Think better of her words, ſhe doth deceive you,
And only for her vaine and ſenſuall ends
Perſwade ye thus. Let me be ſet to dwell
For ever naked in the bareſt ſoile
So you will dwell from hence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I ſee my folly,
Packe up my ſtuffe, I will away this morne.
Haſte—haſte.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I, Now I ſee your Fathers honours
Trebling upon you, and the many prayers
The countrey ſpent for him, which almoſt now
Begun to turn to curſes, turning backe,
And falling like a timely ſhower
Upon ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Goe, call up my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But ſhall ſhe not prevaile,
And ſway you, as ſhe oft hath done before?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not heare her, but raile on her
Till I be ten miles off.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you be forty,
'Twill not be worſe Sir:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Call her up,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why what an Aſſe was I that ſuch a thing
As a wife is could rule me?
Know not I that woman was created for the man,
That her deſires, nay all her thoughts ſhould be
As his are? is my ſenſe reſtor'd at length?
Now ſhe ſhall know, that which ſhe ſhould deſire,
She hath a husband that can govern her,
If her deſires leades me againſt my will;
Are you come?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What ſad unwonted courſe
Makes you raiſe me ſo ſoone, that went to bed
So late laſt-night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O you ſhall goe to bed ſooner hereafter,
And be rais'd againe at thriftie hours,
In Summer-time wee'l walke
An houre after our ſupper, and to bed,
In winter you ſhall have a ſet at Cards,
And ſet your maids to worke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What do you meane?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I wil no more of your new tricks, your honours,
Your offices, and all your large preferments,
Which ſtill you beate into my eares, hang ore me.
I'le leave behind for others, the great ſway
Which I ſhall beare at Court: my living here
With countenance of your honoured friends
I'le be content to looſe: for you ſpeake this
Only that you may ſtill continue here
In wanton eaſe: and draw me to conſume
In cloaths and other things idle for ſhew
That which my Father got with honeſt thrift.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why, who hath been with you Sir,
That you talke thus out of Frame.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You make a foole of me:
You provide one to bid me forth to ſupper
And make me promiſe; then muſt ſome one or other
Invite you forth, if you have borne your ſelfe
Looſely to any Gentleman in my ſight
At home, you ask me how I like the carriage,
Whether it were not rarely for my good,
And open'd not a way to my preferment?
Come I perceive all: talke not, we'le away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why Sir, you'le ſtay till the next triumph
Day be paſt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I, you have kept me here trium●hing
This ſeven yeares, and I have ridden through the ſtreetes,
And bought embroyderd hoſe and foote-cloths too,
To ſhew a ſubjects zeale, I rode before
In this moſt gorgeous habit, and ſaluted
All the acquaintance I could eſpie
From any window, theſe were wayes ye told me
To raiſe me; I ſee all: make you ready ſtraight,
And in that gowne which you came firſt to Town in,
Your ſafe-guard, cloake, and your hood ſutable:
Thus on a duble gelding ſhall you amble,
And my man Jaques ſhall be ſet before you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But will you goe?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And ſhall I too?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And you ſhall too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But ſhall I by this light?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why by this light you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then by this light
You have no care of your eſtate, and mine.
Have we been ſeven years venturing in a ſhip,
And now upon return with a faire winde
And a calme ſea, full fraught with our own wiſhes
Laden with wealth and honour to the brim,
And ſhall we flye away and not receive it?
Have we been tilling, ſowing, labouring
With paine and charge a long and tedious winter,
And when we ſee the corne above the ground,
Youthfull as is the morne and full eare
That promiſes to ſtuffe our ſpatious garners,
Shall we then let it rot, and never reap it?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wife talke no more, your Retoricke comes too late,
I am inflixable; and how dere you
Adventure to direct my courſe of life?
Was not the husband mad to rule the wife?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis true but where the man doth miſſe his way,
It is the womans part to ſet him right;
So Fathers have a power to guide their Sonnes
In all their courſes, yet you oft have ſeene
Poore litle children that have both their eyes
Lead their blind Fathers.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: She has a plaguy witt,
I ſay you'r but a little piece of man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But ſuch a peice, as being tane away
Man cannot laſt: the faireſt and talleſt ſhip,
That ever ſaild, is by a little peice of the ſame
Wood, ſteerd right, and turnd about.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis true ſhe ſayes, her anſwers ſtand with reaſon.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But Sir, your Cozin put this in your head
Who is an enemie to your preferment,
Becauſe I ſhould not take place of his wife;
Come by this kiſſe thou ſhalt not go ſweete heart.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Come, by this kiſſe I will goe Sweet-heart,
On with your riding ſtuffe; I know your tricks,
And if preferment fall ere you be ready,
'Tis welcome, elſe adue the Citie life.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well Sir I will obey.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About it then,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To pleaſe your humour I would dreſſe my ſelfe,
In the moſt loathſome habit you could name
Or travell any whether ore the world
If you command me, it ſhall neere be ſaid
The fraylty of a woman whoſe weake minde,
Is often ſet on looſe delights and ſhewes,
Hath drawne her husband to conſume his ſtate,
In the vaine hope of that which never fell.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: About it then, women are pleaſant creatures,
When once a man begins to know himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But harke you Sir becauſe I wilbe ſure,
You ſhall have no excuſe, no word to ſay
In your defence hereafter; when you ſee
What honours were preparde for you and me
Which you thus willingly have throwne away,
I tell you I did looke for preſent honour,
This morning for you, which I know had come
But if they do not come ere I am ready
(Which I will be the ſooner leaſt they ſhould)
When I am once ſet in a countrey life,
Not all the power of earth ſhall alter me,
Not all your prayers or threats ſhall make me ſpeak
The Leaſt words to my honourable freinds
To do you any grace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And never more hope to be honourable,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My hopes are lower.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: As I live you ſhall not,
You ſhall be ſo farr from the name of noble
That you ſhall never ſee a Lord againe;
You ſhall not ſee a maske, or Barriers,
Or tilting or a ſolemn chriſtning,
Or a great marriage, or new fire-works,
Or any bravery; but you ſhall live
At home beſpotted with your owne loved durt
In ſcurvy cloathes as you were wont to doe,
And to content you I will live ſo too.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis all I wiſh, make haſt the day drawes on,
It ſhall be my care to ſee your ſtuffe pact up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It ſhal be my care to gul you: you ſhal ſtay. Ex. Gen.
And more then ſo intreat me humbly too
You ſhall have honours preſently; Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Bring hither, pen, inke, and paper.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your Maſter Will not ſtay,
Unleſſe preferment come within an houre.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let him commande one of the Citie gates
In time of mutiny, or you may provide him,
To be one of the counſell for invading,
Some ſavage countrey to plant chriſtian faith.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, I have it for him, call my page
Now my deare husband there it is will fit you. Exit. Maria
And when the world ſhall ſee what I have done,
Let it not move the ſpleene of any wife,
To make an aſſe of her beloved husband
Without good ground, but if they will be drawne
To any reaſon by you, do not gull them;
But if they grow conceited of themſelves,
And be fine Gentlemen, have no mercie,
Publiſh them to the world, 'twill do them good
When they ſhall ſee their follies underſtood,
Go beare theſe letters to my ſervant,
And bid him make haſt, I will dreſſe my ſelfe,
In all the journey cloathes I uſed before
Not to ride but to make the laughter more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is all pact up?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: All, all Sir, there is no tumbler,
Runs throw his hoop with more dexteritie
Then I aboute this buſineſſe: tis a day
That I have long longd to ſee.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come wheres my ſpurs?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here Sir, and now 'tis come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques now
I thanke my fates, I can command my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am glad to ſee it Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I do not love alwayes,
To be made a puppie, Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But yet me thinkes your worſhip does not looke,
Right like a countrey Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will, give me my tother hat.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: So, my Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: On with it Jaques, thou and I
Will live ſo finely in the countrey, Jaques,
And have ſuch pleaſant walks into the woods
A mornings, and then bring whom riding rods,
And walking ſtaves—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And I will beare them Sir,
And skurdge-ſticks for the children.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: So thou ſhalt,
And thou ſhalt do all, over ſee my worke folkes
And at the weekes end pay them all their wages.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will Sir, ſo your worſhip give me mony.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt receive all too: give me my drawers

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: They are ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And I will make thy Miſtriſs,
My wife, looke to her landrie and her dayry,
That we may have our linnen cleane on Sundayes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And holy dayes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I and ere we walke about the grounds
Provide our breake-faſt,
Or ſhe ſhall ſmoke, I'le have her a good huswife
She ſhall not make a voyage to her ſiſters,
But ſhe ſhall live at home,
And feed her pullen fat, and ſee her maides
In bed before her, and locke all the doores

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why that will be a life for Kings and Queenes.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Give me my Scarfe with the great button quickly.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: 'Tis done Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Now my Mittens.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Here they are Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis well? now my great dagger.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why ſo; thus it ſhould be, now my riding rod.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: There's nothing wanting Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Another, man, to ſticke under my girdle.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: There it is.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: All is well.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Why now me thinks your Worſhip looks
Like to your ſelfe, a man of meanes and credit,
So did your grave and famous Anceſtors,
Ride up and down to faires, and cheapen cattell.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Goe, haſten your Miſtriſſe, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: It ſhall be done. Exit Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who's that? who's that boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I thinke it be my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who, he that walkes in gray whisking his riding rod?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes Sir, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed; he is prepar'd
For his new journey; when I wink upon you
Runne out and tell the Gentleman 'tis time—
Monſieur good day.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Monſieur your Miſtriſſe is within, but yet not ready.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My buſineſſe is with you Sir; 'tis reported,
I know not whether by ſome enemie
Maliciouſly that envies your great hopes,
And would be ready to ſow diſcontents
Betwixt his Majeſty and you, or truly,
Which on my faith I would be ſorry for,
That you intend to leave the Court in haſt.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Faith Sir within this halfe houre. Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaques within:
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Is my wife ready?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Preſently.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But Sir,
I needs muſt tell you as I am your friend,
You ſhould have tane your journey privater
For 'tis already blaz'd about the Court.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why Sir, I hope it is no Treaſon, is it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir, but 'tis grown the common talk,
There's no diſcovery elſe held, and in the preſence
All the Nobility and Gentry
Have nothing in their mouths but only this,
Monſieur Marine that noble Gentleman,
Is now departing hence, every mans face
Looks ghaſtly on his fellows, ſuch a ſadneſſe
(Before this day) I nere beheld in Court,
Mens hearts begin to faile them when they heare it,
In expectation of the great event
That needs muſt follow it, pray heaven it be good!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why I had rather all their hearts ſhould faile
Then I ſtay here untill my purſe faile me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But yet you are a Subject, and beware
I charge you by the love I beare to you
How you doe venture raſhly on a courſe
To make your ſoveraign jealous of your deeds
For Princes jealouſies where they love moſt,
Are eaſily found, but they be hardly loſt.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Come theſe are tricks, I ſmell 'em, I will goe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Have I not ſtill profeſt my ſelfe your friend?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Yes, but you never ſhewd it to me yet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But now I will, becauſe I ſee you wiſe,
And give ye thus much light into a buſineſſe
That came to me but now, be reſolute,
Stand ſtifly to it that you will depart,
And preſently.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why ſo I meane to doe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And by this light you may be what you will;
Will you be ſecret Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The King does feare you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And is now in Counſell;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About me;

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: About you, and you be wiſe,
You'l finde hee's in Counſell about you?
His Councellours have told him all the truth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What truth?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why? that which now he knows too well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: That you have followed him ſeven years
With a great traine: and though he have not grac't you,
Yet you have div'd into the hea ts of thouſands,
With liberality and noble carriage;
And if you ſhould depart home unprefer'd
All diſcontented, and ſeditious ſpirits
Would flocke to you and thruſt you into action:
With whoſe help, & your Tenants, who doth not know
(If you were ſo diſpos'd:)
How great a part of this yet fertile peaceful realm of Fran.
You might make deſolate? but when the King
Heard this —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: what ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nothing, but ſhook,
As never Chriſtian Prince did ſhake before.
And to be ſhort you may be what you will?
But be not ambitious Sir, ſit downe
With moderate honours, leaſt you make your ſelfe
More feard.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know Sir what I have to doe
In mine own buſineſſe. Enter Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Where's Monſieur Mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why there he ſtands, will you ought with him?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Yes: Good day Monſieur Marine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: His Majeſty doth commend himſelfe,
Moſt kindly to you Sir, and hath by me,
Sent you this favour: kneele downe, riſe a Knight.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I thank his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And he doth further requeſt you,
Not to leave the Court ſo ſoone,
For though your former merits have been ſlighted,
After this time there ſhall no Office fall;
Worthy your ſpirit, as he doth confeſſe
There's none ſo great, but you ſhall ſurely have it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Do you heare, if you yield yet you are an aſſe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I'le ſhew my ſervice to his Majeſty
In greater things then theſe, but for this ſmall one
I muſt intreat his Highneſſe to excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'le beare your Knightly words unto the King,
And bring his Princely anſwer backe againe. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: VVell ſaid, be reſolute a while, I know
There is a tide of honours comming on.
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: VVhere is this new made Knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let me enfold you in my arms,
Then call you Lord, the King will have it ſo,
Who doth entreat your Lordſhip to remember
His meſſage ſent to you by Longavile.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If ye be durty, and dare not mount aloft;
You may yield now, I know what I would do.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace, I will fit him; tell his Majeſty
I am a Subject, and I do confeſſe
I ſerve a gracious Prince, that thus hath heapt
Honours on me without deſert, but yet
As for the meſſage, buſineſſe urgeth me,
I muſt be gone, and he muſt pardon me,
Were he ten thouſand Kings and Emperours.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I'le tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, this was like your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: As he hath wrought him, 'tis the fineſt fellow
That ere was Chriſtmas Lord, he carries it
So truly to the life, as though he were
One of the plot to gull himſelfe. Exit Bewf.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why ſo, you ſent the wiſeſt and the ſhrewdeſt
Unto the King, I ſwear, my honoured friend
That ever any Subject ſent his Liege.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay now I know I have him on the hip,
I'le follow it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My honourable Lord,
Give me your noble hand right courteous Peer,
And from henceforth be a courtly Earl;
The King ſo wills, and Subjects muſt obey:
Only he doth deſire you to conſider
Of his requeſt.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why faith your well my Lord, yield to him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yield? why 'twas my plot.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nay 'twas your wives plot.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: To get preferment by it,
And thinks he now to pop me ith mouth
But with an Earldome, Ile be one ſtep higher.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis the fineſt Lord, I am afraid anon
He will ſtand upon't to ſhare the Kingdome with him.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Wher's this Courtly Earle?
His Majeſty commends his love unto you;
And will you but now grant to his requeſt,
He bids you be a Duke, and chuſe of whence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why if you yield not now, you are undone,
What can you wiſh to have more, but the Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So pleaſe his Majeſty, I would be Du. of Burgundy
Becauſe I like the place.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I Know the King is pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then will I ſtay and kiſſe his Highneſſe hand.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: His Majeſty wil be a glad man when he hears it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: But how ſhall we keep this from the worlds eare
That ſome one tell him not, he is no Duke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Wee'l think of that anon.
Why Gentlemen, is this a gracious habit for a Duke?
Each gentle body ſet a finger to
To pluck the clouds of this his riding weeds
From off the orient ſunne of his beſt cloths;
I'le pluck one boot and ſpur off.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I another.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Ile pluck his Jerkin off.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sit down my Lord;
Both his ſpurs off at once good Longavile
And Bewford take that ſcarfe off, and that hat
Doth not become his largely ſprouting fore-head.
Now ſet your gracious foot to this of mine,
One pluck will do it, ſo, off with the other.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Loe thus your ſervant Longavile doth pluck
The trophy of your former gentry off,
Off with his Jerkin Bewford.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Didſt thou never ſee
A nimble footed Taylor ſtand ſo in his ſtockings,
Whilſt ſome friend help to pluck his Jerkin off,
To dance a Jigg?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Here's his man Jaques come
Booted and ready ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My Miſtris ſtayes;
Why how now Sir? what do your Worſhip mean,
To plucke your grave and thrifty habit off?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My ſlippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O thou mighty Duke
Pardon this man,
That thus hath treſpaſſed in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I pardon him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: His Graces ſlippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Foot-man, hee's a Duke:
The King hath rais'd him above all his land.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le to his Couzen preſently, and tell him ſo;
O what a dung-hill countrey rogue was I! Exit Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: See, ſee, my Miſtriſſe.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Let's obſerve their greeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Unto your will as every good wife ought,
I have turnd all my thoughts, and now am ready.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O Wife I am not worthy to kiſſe the leaſt
Of all thy toes, much leſſe thy thumb,
Which yet I would be bold with; all thy counſell
Hath been to me Angelicall, but mine to thee
Hath been moſt durty like my mind:
Deare Ducheſſe I muſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What are you mad to make me
Dreſſe, and undreſſe, turne and winde me,
Becauſe you find me plyant? ſaid I not
The whole world ſhould not alter me, if once
I were reſolv'd? and now you call me Ducheſſe:
Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Loe a Knight doth kneel.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A Knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A Lord.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A foole.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I ſay doth kneele an Earle, a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In drawers.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Without ſhoes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sure you are lunatick.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No honoured Ducheſſe
If you dare but believe your ſervants truth,
I know he is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: God ſave his Grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I aske your Graces pardon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I riſe,
And here in token that all ſtrife ſhall end
'Twixt thee and me, I let my drawers fall
And to thy hands I do deliver them:
Which ſignifies, that in all acts and ſpeeches,
From this time forth my wife ſhall wear the breeches.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: An honourable compoſition. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Shall I beleeve thee Iaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir you may.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Didſt thou not dreame?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I did not.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Nor imagine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Neither of both: I ſaw him great and mighty,
I ſaw the Monſieurs bow, and heard them cry
Good health and fortune to my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: A Duke art ſure? a Duke?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am ſure a Duke,
And ſo ſure as I know my ſelfe for Jaques.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Yet the ſun may dazell? Jaques, was it not
Some leane Commander of an angry Block-houſe
To keep the ſleamiſh Eele-boats from invaſion,
Or ſome bold Baron able to diſpend
His fifty pounds a yeare, and meet the foe
Upon the Kings command in gilded canvas,
And do his deeds of worth? or was it not
Some place of gaine, as Clerk to the great Band
Of maribones, that people call the Switzers?
Men made of beufe, and ſarcenet?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Is a Duke his chamber hung with Nobles like a preſence?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I am ſomething wavering in my faith;
Would you would ſettle me, and ſweare 'tis ſo,
Is he a Duke indeed?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I ſweare he is.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied, he is my Kinſman. Jaques,
And I his poor unworthy Couzen.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: True Sir.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I might have been a Duke too, I had meanes,
A wife as faire as his, and as wiſe as his;
And could have brookt the Court as well as his,
And laid about her for her husbands honour:
O Jaques had I ever dreamt of this,
I had prevented him.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith Sir it came
Above our expectation, we were wiſe
Only in ſeeking to undoe this honour,
Which ſhewed our dung-hill breeding and our durt.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: But tell me Iaques,
Why could we not perceive? what dull Divell
Wrought us to croſſe this noble courſe, perſwading
'Twould be his overthrow? for me a Courtier
Is he that knows all, Iaques, and does all,
'Tis as his noble Grace hath often ſaid,
And very wiſely, Jaques, we are fooles,
And underſtand juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I, as we were, I confeſſe it.
But riſing with our great Maſter,
We ſhall be call'd to knowledge with our places,
'Tis nothing to be wiſe, not thus much there,
Ther's not the leaſt of the billet dealers,
Nor any of the Paſtry, or the Kitchin,
But have it in meaſure delicate.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Me thinks this greatneſs of the Dukes my Couzens
(I aske you mercy, Iaques, that near name
Is too familiar for me) ſhould give promiſe
Of ſome great benefits to his attendants.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I have a ſuite my ſelfe, and it is ſure,
Or I miſtake my ends much.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: What is 't Iaques,
May I not crave the place?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir you ſhall,
'Tis to be but his Graces Secretary,
Which is my little all, and my ambition,
Till my known worth ſhall take me by the hand
And ſet me higher; how the fates may do
In this poor threed of life is yet uncertaine;
I was not born I take it for a trencher,
Nor to eſpouſe my Miſtris Dairy-maid.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I am reſolv'd my wife ſhall up to Court;
I'le furniſh her, that is a ſpeeding courſe,
And cannot chuſe but breed a mighty fortune;
What a fine youth was I, to let him ſtart,
And get the riſe before me? I'le diſpatch
And put my ſelfe in moneys.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Maſſe 'tis true,
And now you talke of money, Sir my buſineſſe
For taking thoſe Crowns muſt be diſpatcht?
This litle plot in the Countrey lies moſt fit
To do his Grace ſuch ſerviceable uſes,
I muſt about it.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Yet before you goe
Give me your hand, and bear my humble ſervice
To the great Duke your Maſter, and his Ducheſſe,
And live your ſelfe in favour: ſay my wife
Shall there attend them ſhortly, ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le ſee you mounted Sir.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: It may not be,
Your place is far above it, ſpare your ſelfe,
And know I am your ſervant, fare ye well. Exit Couſen.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir I ſhall reſt to be commanded by you;
This place of Secretary will not content me,
I muſt be more and greater, let me ſee,
To be a Baron is no ſuch great matter
As people take it: for ſay I were a Count,
I am ſtill an under perſon to this Duke,
Which me thinks ſounds but harſhly: but a Duke?
O I am ſtrangely taken, 'tis a Duke
Or nothing, I'le adviſe upont, and ſee
What may be done by wit and induſtry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It muſt be carried cloſely with a care
That no man ſpeak unto him, or come near him
Without our private knowledge, or be made
Afore-hand to our practice:
My good husband
I ſhall entreat you now to ſtay a while,
And prove a noble coxcomb:
Gentlemen,
Your counſell and advice about this carriage.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Alas good man, I do begin to mourn
His dire maſſacre: what a perſecution
Is pouring down upon him? ſure he is ſinfull.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let him be kept in 's chamber under ſhew
Of ſtate and dignity, and no man ſufferd
To ſee his noble face, or have acceſſe,
But we that are Conſpirators.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Or elſe down with him into the countrey amongſt his Tenants,
There he may live far longer in his greatneſſe,
And play the foole in pomp amongſt his fellows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, he ſhall play the foole in the City, and ſtay
I will not looſe the greatneſſe of this jeſt
That ſhal be given to my wit for the whole revenues.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Then thus wee'l have a guard about his perſon,
That no man come too neare him, and ourſelves
Alwayes in company; have him into the City
To ſee his face ſwell; whilſt in divers corners,
Some of our own appointing ſhall be ready
To cry heaven bleſſe your Grace, long live your Grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Servant, your counſells excellent good,
And ſhall be followed, twill be rarely ſtrange
To ſee him ſtated thus, as though he went
A ſhroving through the City, or intended
To ſet up ſome new ſtake:
I ſhall not hold
From open laughter when I heare him crye
Come hither my ſweet Dutcheſſe: let me kiſſe
Thy gracious lips: for this will be his phraſes?
I feare me nothing but his legs will breake
Und●r his mighty weight of ſuch a greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Now me thinks deareſt Lady you are too cruell;
His very heart will freeze in knowing this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, the man was never of ſuch deepneſſe
To make conceite his Maſter: Sir I'le aſſure ye
He will out-live twenty ſuch pageants.
Were he but my Cozen or my Brother,
And ſuch a deſperate killer of his fortune,
In this beliefe he ſhould dye, though it coſt me
A thouſand crowns a day to hold it up;
Or were I not known his wife, and ſo to have
An equall feeling of this ill he ſuffers,
He ſhould be thus till all the boyes i'th Towne
Made ſute to weare his badges in their hats,
And walke before his Grace with ſticks and noſe-gayes,
We married women hold—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Tis well, no more.
The Duke is entring, ſet your faces right,
And bow like Countrey prologues: here he comes.
Make roome afore, the Duke is entring.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The cheifeſt fortunes waite upon our Duke,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And give him all content and happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let his great name live to the end of time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We thank you, and are pleas'd to give you notice
We ſhall at fitter times wait on your Loves,
Till when, be neare Us.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: 'Tis a valiant purge, and works extreamly;
'Tas delivered him
Of all Right worſhipfull and gentle humours,
And left his belly full of nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It pleaſed the King my Maſter
For ſundry vertues not unknown to him,
And the all-ſeeing ſtate, to lend his hand
And raiſe me to this Emminence, how this
May ſeeme to other men, or ſtir the mindes
Of ſuch as are my fellow Peers, I know not,
I would deſire their loves in juſt deſignes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now by my faith he does well, very well:
Beſhrew my heart I have not ſeen a better
Of a raw fellow, that before this day
Never rehearſt his ſtate: 'tis marvellous well.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Is he not Duke indeed, ſee how he lookes
As if his ſpirit were a laſt, or two
Above his veines, and ſtretcht his noble hide.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Hee's high brac't like a drum, pray God he breake not.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why let him break, ther's but a Calves-skin loſt.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your Grace to ſee the City,
Twill be to the minds and much contentment
Of the doubtfull people.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am determin'd ſo, till my returne
I leave my honoured Dutcheſſe to her chamber.
Be carefull of your health, I pray you be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your grace ſhall ſuffer us your humble ſervants
To give attendance fit ſo great a perſon
Upon your body.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am pleaſed ſo.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Away good Bewford, raiſe a guard ſufficient
To keep him from the reach of tongues, be quicke;
And do you heare, remember how the ſtreets
Muſt be diſpos'd with for cryes, and ſalutations.
Your grace determines not to ſee the King—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Not yet, I ſhall be ready ten dayes hence
To kiſſe his highneſſe hand, and give him thanks,
As it is fit I ſhould for his great bounty
Set forward Goentlemen.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Room for the Duke there. Exeunt Duke & traine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis ſit he ſhould have room to ſhew his mightineſſe,
He ſwels ſo with his poyſon,
'Tis better to reclaim ye thus, then make
A ſheeps-head of you, It had been but your due;
But I have mercy Sir, and mean to reclaim you
By a directer courſe.
That woman is not worthy of a ſoule
That has the ſoveraign power to rule her husband,
And gives her title up, ſo long provided
As there be faire play, and his ſtate not wrongd.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I would be glad to know whence this new Duke ſprings,
The people buz abroad, or by what title
He received his dignity, 'tis very ſtrange
There ſhould be ſuch cloſe jugling in the State,
But I am tyed to ſilence, yet a day
May come, and ſoone to perfect all theſe doubts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It is the mad Shattillion by my ſoule
I ſuffer much for this poor Gentleman;
I'le ſpeake to him, may be he yet knows me.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Can you give me reaſon from whence
This great Duke ſprang that walkes abroad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Even from the King himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: As you are a woman, I think you may be coverd
Yet your prayer would do no harm good woman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God preſerve him.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I ſay Amen, and ſo ſay all good ſubjects.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Lady as ever you have lov'd, or ſhall,
As you have hope of heaven lend your hand,
And wit to draw this poore diſtracted man
Under your roofe from the broad eyes of people,
And wonder of the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: With all my heart;
My feeling of his griefe and loſſe is much.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Sir now you are come ſo neare the priſon, wil ye
Goe in, and viſit your fair Love: poore ſoule
She would be glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This ſame Duke is but
Apocryphall, there's no creation
That can ſtand where titles are not right.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is another draught upon my life;
Let me examine well the words I ſpake.
The words I ſpake were, that this novell Duke
Is not ot'h true making, 'tis to me moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are as right Sir as you went by line.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And to the griefe of many thouſands more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If there be any ſuch, God comfort them.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Whoſe mouths may open when the time ſhall pleaſe;
I'me betraid, commend me to the King,
And tell him I am ſound, and crave but juſtice;
You ſhall not need to have your guard upon me,
Which I am ſure are plac'd for my attachment;
Lead on; I'm obedient to my bonds.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good Sir be not diſpleaſed with us;
We are but ſervants to his highneſſe will,
To make that good.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I doe forgive you even with my heart;
Shall I entreat a favour?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: To ſee my love before that fatall ſtroake,
And publiſh to the world my chriſtian death,
And true obedience to the Crown of France.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I hope it ſhall not need Sir, for there is mercy
As well as juſtice in his Royall heart. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Every man take his corner, here am I,
You there, and you in that place, ſo be perfect,
Have a great care your cryes be loud; and faces
Full of dejected feare and humbleneſſe.
He comes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Fye how theſe ſtreets are charg'd and ſwoll'd
With theſe ſame raſcally people? give more room,
Or I ſhall have occaſion to diſtribute
A martial almes amongſt you; as I am a Gentleman
I have not ſeen ſuch rude diſorder,
They follow him like a prize, there's no true gaper
Like to your Citizen, he will be ſure
The beares ſhall not paſſe by his door in peace,
But he and all his family will follow.
Roome there afore? Sound?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Give roome, and keep your places
And you may ſee enough; keep your places.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Theſe people are too far unmanner'd, thus
To ſtop your Graces way with multitudes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Rebuke them not good Monſieur 'tis their loves
Which I will anſwer, if it pleaſe my ſtars
To ſpare me life and health.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Bleſſe your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Now heaven preſerve your happy days:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you too.

sp.speaker: 3 Gen.
sp.l: Now heaven ſave your Grace;

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thanke you all.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: On there before.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Stand Gentlemen, ſtay yet a while,
For I am minded to impart my love
To theſe good people, and my friends
Whoſe love and prayers for my greatneſſe,
Are equall in abundance, note me well,
And with my words; my heart? for as the tree—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your Grace had beſt beware, 'twil be inform'd
Your greatneſſe with the people.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I had more
My honeſt and ingenious people.—But
The weight of buſineſſe hath prevented me.
I am call'd from you: but this tree I ſpake of
Shall bring forth fruit I hope to your content,
And ſo I ſhare my bowels amongſt you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A noble Duke, a very noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Afore there Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You'r faithfully met good Monſieur Mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Be advis'd, the time is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Is he not the ſame man he was afore?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Still the ſame man to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have received mighty grace, be thankfull.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Let me not dye in ignorance;

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You ſhall not.
Then know the King out of his loue hath pleaſed
To ſtile him Duke of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: O great Duke,
Thus low, I plead for pardon, and deſire
To be enrol'd amongſt your pooreſt ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sir you have mercy, and withall my hand,
From henceforth let me call you one of mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Make room afore there, and diſmiſſe the people.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Every man to his houſe in peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: Peop.
sp.l: Now heaven preſerve the Duke, heaven bleſſe the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This letter came this morn from my Cozen
To the great Lady, high and mighty Ducheſſe
Of Burgundy, be theſe delivered O,
For a ſtronger lace to keep my breath
That I may laugh the nine dayes till the wonder
Fall to an ebb: the high and mighty Ducheſſe?
The high and mighty God? what a ſtile is this?
Methinks it goes like a Duchy lope-man,
A ladder of 100. rounds will faile
To reach the top on't, well my Gentle Cozen
I know by theſe contents your itch of honour;
You muſt to the Court, you ſay, and very ſhortly:
You ſhall be welcome; and if your wife have wit
I'le put her in a thriving courſe, if not
Her own ſin on her owne head, not a blot
Shall ſtaine my reputation, only this
I muſt for healths ſake ſometimes
Make an aſſe of the tame moyle my husband;
'Twill do him good, and give him freſher brains,
Me freſher blood.
Now for the noble Duke, I heare him comming.
Your Grace is well return'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As well as may be:
Never in younger health, never more able:
I meane to be your bed-fellow this night,
Let me have good encounter.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Bleſſe me heaven
What a hot meat this greatneſſe is?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: It may be ſo,
For I'le be ſworn he hath not got a ſnap
This two months on my knowledge, or her woman
Is damd for ſwearing it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen for your attendance
And alſo your great paines, pray know my lodgings
Better and oftner, do ſo Gentlemen.
Now by my honour, as I am a Prince,
I ſpeake ſincerely, know my lodgings better,
And be not ſtrangers, I ſhall ſee your ſervice
And your deſervings, when you leaſt expect.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We humbly thank your Grace for this great favor.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be ready for the Countrey,
And let my Tenants know the Kings great love:
Say I would ſee them, but the waight at Court
Lyes heavy on my ſhoulders: let them know
I do expect their duties in attendance
Againſt the next feaſt, wait for my comming
To take up poſt horſe, and be full of ſpeed. Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I would deſire your Grace—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You ſhall deſire, and have your
Full deſire, ſweet Ducheſſe ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To have ſome conference with a Gentleman
That ſeems not altogether void of reaſon?
He talks of titles, and things neare the Crown,
And knowing none ſo fit as your good Grace,
To give the difference in ſuch points of State—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is he? If he be noble, or have any part
That's worthy our converſe, We do accept him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can aſſure your Grace his ſtraine is noble,
But he's very ſubtle.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let him be ſo.
Let him have all the braines, I ſhall demonſtrate
How this moſt Chriſtian Crown of France can beare
No other ſhew of title then the Kings.
I will goe in and meditate for halfe an houre,
And then be ready for him preſently,
I will convert him quickly or confound him.

sp.speaker: Ser
sp.l: Is mad Shattillion here?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Is here, and's Lady,
I prethee ſervant fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, what do you meane to put him to?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To chat with the mad lad my husband;
'Twill be brave to heare them ſpeake, babl,
Stare, and prate.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: But what ſhall be the end of all this, Lady?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Leave that to me, now for the grand diſpute,
For ſee here comes Shattillion: as I live me thinks
All France ſhould beare part of his griefes.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I le fetch my Lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Where am I now, or whether will you lead me?
To my death? I crave my priviledge,
I muſt not dye but by juſt courſe of law.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: His Majeſty hath ſent by me your pardon,
He meant not you ſhould dye; but would intreate you
To lay the full ſtate of your Title open,
Unto a grave and noble Gentleman.
The Duke of Burgundy who here doth come,
Who either by his wiſedome will confute you,
Or elſe informe and ſatisfie the King.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: May 't pleaſe your grace, this is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this he that chops ●ogicke with my liege?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Dee mocke me? you are great, the time will come
When you ſhall be as much contemned as I,
Where are the ancient complements of France,
That upſtarts brave the Princes of the bloud?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your title Sir, in ſhort.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: He muſt Sir,
Be a better ſtates man then your ſelfe, that can
Trip me in any thing, I will not ſpeake
Before theſe witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Depart the roome, for none ſhall ſtay,
No not my deareſt Dutches.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wee'le ſtand behind the Arras & heare all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In that chaire take your place, I in this,
Diſcourſe your title now.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir you ſhall know,
My loves true title, mine by marriage,
Setting aſide the firſt race of French Kings
Which will not here concerne us, as Pharamond,
With Clodian, Meron, and Chilperik,
And to come downe unto the ſecond race,
Which we will likewiſe ſlip—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But take me with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave, of Martell Charles,
The Father of King Pippin, who was, Sir,
To Charles the great and famous Charlemaine.
And to come to the third race of French Kings,
Which will not be great ly pertinent in this cauſe,
Betwixt the King and me, of which you know
HVGH CAPET was the firſt,
Next his Sonne Robert, Henry then, and Phillip
With Lewis, and his Sonne a Lewis too,
And of that name the ſeventy, but all this
Springs from a female as it ſhall appeare.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now give me leave, I grant you this your title
At the firſt ſight carryes ſome ſhew of truth;
But if ye weigh it well ye ſhall finde light.
Is not his Majeſtie poſſeſt in peace,
And juſtice executed in his name,
And can you thinke the moſt Chriſtian King
Would do this if he ſaw not reaſon for it?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But had not the tenth Lewis a ſole daughter?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But anſwer me directly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is a moſt ſeditious queſtion.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Is this your juſtice?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I ſtand for my King.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Was ever heire apparant thus abus'd?
I'le have your head for this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, do your worſt.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Will no one ſtir to apprehend this traytor?
A guard about my perſon will? none come?
Muſt my owne royall hands performe the deede?
Then thus I do arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Treaſon, help.

div.stage: Enter Wife, Long, and Bew. and Servant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Help, help, my Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Help thy Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Forbeare his graces perſon.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Forbeare you to touch him that,
Your heire apparant weds,
But by this hand I will have all your heads. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How doth your grace?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why? well.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How do you finde his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis a dangerous one,
As can come by a female.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I 't is true,
But the law Salicke, cuts him off from all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I do beſeech your grace how ſtands his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pew, nothing, the law Shallicke cuts him off from all

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My gracious husband you muſt now prepare,
In all your graces pomp to entertaine
Your cozen, who is now a convertite,
And followes here, this night he will be here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be ready all in haſt, I do intend,
To ſhew before my cozens wondring face Exeunt omnes.
The greatneſſe of my pomp, and of my place.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Sirra is all things carried to the Taylor,
The meaſure and the faſhion of the gowne
With the beſt trim?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes Sir & 'twill be ready within this two dayes.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: For my ſelfe I care not,
I have a ſuite or two of ancient velvet;
Which with ſome ſmall correcting and addition
May ſteale into the preſence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would my Gowne were ready husband, I'le lay my life,
To make you ſomething ere to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: It muſt not bee
Before we ſee the Duke, and have advice,
How to behave ourſelves: lets in the while,
And keep our ſelves from knowledge till time ſhall call us

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I much admire the fierce maſculine ſpirit,
Of this dread Amazon.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This following night I'le have a wench in ſolace.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I heare you,
And will be with you if I live, no more.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My Lady would intreate your preſence Gentlman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: We will obey your Lady, ſhe is worthy.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You light alone, a word, or two.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your will Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Harke in your eare, wilt thou be maried? ſpeake, wilt thou marry?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Maried? to whom Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: To a proper fellow, landed, and able bodied,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why do you flout me Sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I ſweare I do not, I love thee for thy Ladies ſake, be free,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If I could meet ſuch matches as you ſpeake of,
I were a very child to looſe my time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What ſaieſt thou to Mounſier Bewford.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir I ſay hee's a proper Gentleman, and far
Above my meanes to looke at.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Doſt thou like him?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and ever did.

sp.speaker: Long
sp.l: He is thine owne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are too greate in promiſes.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be rul'd and follow my advice, he ſhall be thine

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would you would make it good Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Do but thus,
Get thee a cuſhion underneath thy cloathes,
And leave the reſt to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'le be your ſcholler,
I cannot looſe much by the venture ſure.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thou wilt looſe a prettie maiden head, my rogue,
Or I am much o'th bow hand, you'le remember
If all this take effect, who did it for you,
And what I may deſerve for ſuch a kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yours Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Save ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray you Sir, which is the neareſt way?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King, this is the neareſt way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Which is the neareſt way to the poſt houſe?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: God ſave the King and his poſt horſe.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray Sir direct me to the houſe;

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Heaven ſave the King, you cannot catch me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not underſtand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You do not, I ſay you cannot catch me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not catch you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No Sir, nor can the King,
With all his ſtratagems, and his forced tricks,
Although he put his nobles in diſguiſe;
Never ſo oft to ſift into my words,
By courſe of law, lay hold upon my life.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is buſineſſe that my Lord the Duke
Is by the King imployed in, and he thinks
I am acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I ſhall not need to ripp the cauſe up,
From the firſt to you,
But if his Majeſty had ſuffered me
To marry her, though ſhe be after him,
The right heire generall to the Crowne of France.
I would not have convayed her into Spaine,
As it was thought, nor would I ere have joyn'd,
With the reformed Churches to make them,
Stand for my cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not thinke you would.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir,
And ſince I ſee you are a favorer
Of vertues, kept in bondage;
Tell directly to my ſoveraigne King,
For ſo I will acknowledge him for ever,
How you have found my ſtaid affections
Setled for peace, and for the preſent ſtate.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And good Sir tell him further this,
That notwithſtanding all ſuggeſtions
Brought to him againſt me and all his ſuſpitions,
Which are innumerall to my treaſons,
If he will warrant me but publique tryall,
I'le freely yeild my ſelfe into his hands;
Can he have more then this?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No by my troth.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I would his Majeſty would heare but reaſon,
As well as you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But Sir you do miſtake me,
For I never ſaw the King
In all my life but once, therefore good Sir,
May it pleaſe you to ſhew me which is the poſt houſe.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I cry you mercie Sir, then you'r my freind.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And ſuch men are very rare with me,
The poſt houſe is hard by, farewell;

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, I muſt ride hard to night,
And it is darke already.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am cruell to ſend this man directly to his death
That is my freind, and I might eaſily ſave him,
He ſhall not dye, come backe my freind, come backe.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: do you not know?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And do you gather nothing by my face?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Vertue is ever innocent,
La not the fault on me, I greive for you,
And wiſh that all my teares might win your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Alas good freind you are undone,
The more ill fortune, mine to be the meanes
Of your ſad overthrow: you know not me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No truely Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would you had never ſeene me,
I am a man purſu'd by the whole ſtate
And ſure ſome one hath ſeene me talke with you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes divers Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why then your head is gon.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'le out of towne.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would it were ſoone enough,
Stay if you love your life, or elſe you are taken.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'le venture deeply for him,
Rather then to caſt away an innocent,
Take courage friend, I will preſerve thy life,
With hazard of mine owne.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: This night thou ſhalt be lodg'd within my doores,
Which ſhall be all lookt faſt, and in the morne
I'le ſo provide, you ſhall have free acceſſe,
To the Sea ſide and ſo be ſhipt away,
Ere any know it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good Sir ſuddainly I am afraide to dye.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Then follow me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: This way he went, and there's the houſe I hope,
His better Angell hath directed him,
To leave the wandring ſtreetes, poore Gentleman.
Would I were able with as free a hart,
To ſet his ſoule right, as I am to grieue,
The ruine of his fame, which God forgive me;
Sir if you be within, I pray Sir ſpeake to me.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am within and will be, what are you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: No Sir you muſt pardon me,
I am acquainted with none ſuch: be ſpeedy,
Friend there is no other remedy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A word Sir I ſay I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: You cannot ſcape by any other meanes,
Be not feareful, God ſave the King,
What's your buſineſſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: To ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Speake out then?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Shall I not come up?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not: flye if thou beeſt thin own friend,
There lyes the ſute and all the furniture
Belonging to the head, on with it friend.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir do you heare?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I do, God bleſſe the King,
It was a habit I had laid aſide,
For my owne perſon if the ſtate had forced me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good Sir unlocke your dore.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Be full of ſpeede, I ſee ſome 20 Musketeeres in ambuſh,
What ere thou art, know I am here and will be,
Seeſt thou this bloody ſword that cryes revenge?
Shake not my friend, through millions of theſe foes
I'le be thy guard and ſet thee ſafe aboard.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Dare you not truſt me Sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: My good before me,
And my alleagance to the King I tell thee
Captaine (for ſo I gueſſe thee by thy armes)
And the looſe flancks of halberdeeres about thee,
Thou art too weake and fooliſh to attempt me.
If you be ready follow me, and harke you
Upon your life ſpeake to no living wight,
Except my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not call agen; thus with my ſword,
And the ſtrong faith I beare unto the King;
Whom God preſerve, I will deſcend my chamber,
And cut thy throate, I ſweare I'le cut thy throate,
Steale after me and live.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I will not ſtay.
The furie of a man ſo farr diſtracted. Exit Love.
