Where's the Officer that dares not enter,
To intrap the life of my diſtreſſed friend?
I, have you hid your ſelfe? you muſt be found,
What do you feare? is not authority on your ſide
Nay, I know the Kings command
Will be your warrant, why then feare you? ſpeake
What ſtrange deſignes are theſe? Shattillion,
Be reſolute and beare thy ſelfe upright,
Though the whole world deſpiſe thee: ſoft, me thinks.
I heard a ruſhing which was like the ſhake
Of a diſcovered Officer, I'le ſearch
The whole ſtreete over, but I'le finde thee out. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Jaques. in womens a parrell.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How my joyntes do ſhake, where had I been
But for this worthy Gentleman, that
Hath ſome touch of my infortunes: would I were
Safe under hatches once for Callicut,
Farewell the pomp of Court, I never more
Can hope to be a Duke or any thing,
I never more ſhall ſee thy glorious face;
Of my faire ſpreading Lord that loved me well.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Flye you ſo faſt? I had a ſight of you,
But would not follow you; I was too wiſe,
You ſhall not lead me with a cunning tricke,
Where you may catch me; poore Shatillion;
Hath the Kings anger left thee never a friend?
No, all mens loves move by the breath of Kings.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is the Gent. that ſav'd my life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Bleſſe Shatillion, another plot.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No Sir, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why, who are you?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your friend whom you preſerved.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Whom I preſerved?
My friend? I have no woman friend but one,
Who is to cloſe in priſon to be here;
Come neere let me looke on you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: You ſhould not be a woman by your ſtature.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am none Sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I know it, then keepe off,
Strange men and times! how I am ſtill preſerv'd?
Here they have ſent a yeoman of the guard
Diſguis'd in womans cloathes to worke on me,
To make love to me; and to trap my words,
And ſo inſnare my life, I know you Sir,
Stand back upon your perill, can this bee
In chriſtian common weales? from this time forth
I'le cut off all the meanes to worke on me.
I'le nere ſtirr from my houſe: and keep my doores
Lockt day and night, and cheapen meat and drink
At the next ſhops by ſignes, out of my window,
And having bought it draw it up in my garters.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir, will you help me?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Do not follow me,
I'le take a courſe to live deſpight of men. Exit Shat.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He dares not venture for me, wretched Jaques
Thou art undone for ever and for ever,
Never to riſe againe: what ſhall I do?
Where ſhall I hide me? heres one to take me,
I muſt ſtand cloſe, and not ſpeake for my life.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This is the time of night, and this the haunte,
In which I uſe to catch my wasccoatieres,
It is not very darke, no I ſhall ſpie 'em,
I have walkt out in ſuch a pitchy night.
I could not ſee my fingers this farr off,
And yet have brought whom venſon by the ſmell,
I hope they have not left their old walke, ah?
Have I ſpied you ſitting by this light?
To me theres no ſuch fine ſight in the world,
As a white-apron twixt twelve and one;
See how it gliſters? do you thinke to ſcape?
So now I have you faſt; come and do not ſtrive,
It takes away the edge of appetite;
Come I'le be liberall every way, Exeunt
Take heed you make no noyſe for waking of the watch.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: Now the bleſſing of ſome happy guide,
To bring us to the Duke and we are ready.
Come forward ſee the doore is opend,
And two of his Gent. I'le ſpeake to them,
And marke how I behave my ſelfe, God ſaue yee;
For leſſe I cannot wiſh to men of ſort, & of your ſeeming
Are you of the Dukes?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We are Sir, and your ſervants, your ſalutes,
We give you backe againe with many thankes.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: When did you heare ſuch words before wife? peace,
Do you not dare to anſwer yet; s't fit
So meane a Gentleman as my ſelfe ſhould crave,
The preſence of the great Duke your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir you may.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Shall we deſire your name and buſineſſe Sir,
And wee will preſently informe him of you.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: My name is Cleremont

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You are his graces kinsman,
Or I am much miſtaken;

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: You are right,
Some of his noble blood runs through theſe veines,
Though far unworthy of his graces knowledge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir we muſt all be yours; his graces kinſman,
And we ſo much forgetfull? 'twas a rudeneſſe,
And muſt attend your pardon, thus I crave it:
Firſt to this beauteous Lady, whom I take
To be your wife Sir, next your mercie.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: You have it Sir, I do not like this kiſſing,
It lyes ſo open to a world of wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: This is the merry fellow, this is he
That muſt be noble too.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And ſo he ſhall.
If all the art I have can make him noble,
I'le dub him with a Knight-hood; if his wife
VVill be but forward, and joyne iſſue,
I like her above excellent.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: VVilt pleaſe you
To walke a turne or two, whilſt to the Duke
VVe make your comming known? Exit Ser. & Long.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I ſhal attend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Theſe Gentlemen are very proper men,
And kiſſe the beſt that ere I taſted.
For goodneſſe-ſake husband let us never more
Come neare the Countrey, what ſo ere betide us;
I am in malice with the memory
Of that ſame ſtinking dung-hill.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: VVhy now you are my chicken and my dear,
Love where I love, hate where I hate, now
You ſhall have twenty gownes, and twenty chaines,
See, the doore is opening.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Roome afore there, the Duke is entring.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Wife, Long. Servant, Maria.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.l: 'Tis the Duke, even he himſelfe, be merry,
This is the golden age the Poet ſpeaks on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I pray it be not brazen'd, by their faces,
And yet me thinks they are the neateſt pieces
For ſhape and cutting that ere I beheld.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Moſt gracious Duke, my poor Spouſe & my ſelfe
Do kiſſe your mighty foote, and next to that
The great hand of your Ducheſſe, ever wiſhing
Your honours ever-ſpringing, and your yeares.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Cozen?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Your Graces vaſſall, far unworthy
The nearneſſe of your blood.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Correct me not, I know the word I ſpeake,
And know the perſon.
Though I be ſomething higher then the place
VVhere common men have motion, and diſcending
Down with my eye, their formes are leſſened to me,
Yet from this pitch can I behold my owne,
From millions of thoſe men that have no marke,
And in my fearfull ſtoop, can make them ſtand.
VVhen others feele my ſoule and periſh, Cozen
Be comforted, you are very welcome, ſo
Is your faire wife: the charge of whom I give
To my own deareſt and beſt beloved.
Tell me, have you reſolv'd your ſelfe for Court,
And utterly renounce the ſlaviſh Countrey,
VVith all the cares thereof?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I have ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Have you diſmiſt your eating houſhold,
Sold your hangings of Nebuchadnezar, for ſuch they were,
As I remember, with the furnitures
Belonging to your beds and chambers?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Have you moſt carefully tane off the lead,
From your roofe weake with age, and ſo prevented
The ruine of your houſe, and clapt him
In a ſummer ſuite of thatch to keepe him coole?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: All this I have perform'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then lend me all your hands, I will embrace my Cozen
VVho is an underſtanding Gentleman,
And with a zeale mighty as is my name,
Once more I bid you welcome to the Court;
My ſtate againe.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: As I was telling you your husband
Muſt be no more Commander, looke to that,
Be ſeverall at meate, and lodging, let him have
Boord-wages and dyet 'mongſt his men it'h towne
For pleaſure if he be given too't let him have it,
Elſe as your own fancie ſhall direct you.
Cozen, you ſee this mighty man here: he was an aſſe
When he came firſt to towne: indeed he was
Juſt ſuch another coxcomb as your husband,
God bleſſe the mark and every good mans childe!
This muſt not ſtir you Cozen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Heaven forbid?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sweet Maria, provide the cuſhion ready for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Receive all your advices from our ſelfe,
Be once a day with us, and ſo farewell
For this time, my faire Cozen; Gentlemen
Conduct him to his lodging.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Farewell, and think upon my words.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I ſhall obſerve them. Exit Duke and Ducheſſe.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Health, and the Kings continuall love attend you.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: O for a private place to eaſe my lungs!
Heaven give me patience, ſuch a paire of Jades
Were never better ridden to this houre,
Pray heaven they hold out to the journeys end.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Twitch him aſide good Monſieur, whilſt I breake
Upon the body of his ſtrength, his wife,
I have a conſtant promiſe: ſhe is my own.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Ply her to wind-ward Monſieur, you have taken
The moſt compendious way to raiſe your ſelfe,
That could have been delivered by a councell.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I have ſome certaine aimes Sir: but my wife—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Your wife? you muſt not let that trouble you.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: It will Sir, to ſee her in a ſtrangers armes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What mean you? let her alone, be wiſe, ſtir not a foot
For if you do, all your hopes are buryed:
I ſweare you are a loſt man if you ſtir.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, I will be more advis'd.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But what great Office do you levell at?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Sir, they are kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Let them kiſſe,
And much may do their good hearts; they muſt kiſſe
And kiſſe, and double kiſſe, and kiſſe againe,
Or you may kiſſe the poſt for any riſing:
Had your noble Kinſman ever mounted
To theſe high Spheres of honour, now he moves in,
But for the kiſſes of his wife?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I Know not.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Then I doe; credite me, he had been loſt,
A fellow of no mark, and no repute,
Had not his wife kiſt ſoone, and very ſweetly
She was an excellent woman, and diſpatcht him
To his full, being in a moment Sir— Exit Long. & Wife.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: But yet me thinks he ſhould not take her Sir
Into a private roome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now ſtand and flouriſh,
You are a made man for ever.
I doe envy you if you ſtand your fortunes up,
You are the happieſt man: but your great Cozen
This day in Court: well I will marry ſurely,
And not let every man out-run me thus.
'Tis time to be mine owne friend, I live
In towne here, and direct the readieſt way,
To other men, and be a ſlave my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Nay good Sir be not mov'd, I am your ſervant,
And will not be ungratefull for this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Will you be walking home?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I would de●ire to have my wife a long.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You are too raw,
Be gon and take no notice where you left her,
Let her returne at leiſure, if ſhe ſtay
A moneth 'twill be the better, underſtand me
This Gentleman can doe't. Exit Cozen.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I will Sir, & wife remember me a Duke, a Duke wife.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Aboard her Longaveile ſhee's thine owne,
To me the fooling of this foole, is venerie. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Come, preethe come, have I not crownes? behold
And follow me, here; not a word, go in
Grope by the walls, and you ſhall finde a bed,
Lye downe there, ſee, ſee, a turne or two to give
My blood ſome heate; and I am preſently
For action, darkneſſe by thy leave I come. Exit Bew.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am perfect in my leſſon, be my ſpeed,
Thou God of marriage, this is the doore, I'le knock.

sp.speaker: Bew. within.
sp.l: Whoſe there? I cannot come yet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Mounſier Bewford?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Stay 'till I light a candle, who are ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir? a poore Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: O come in, I'le finde a time for you too, be not loude.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir you have found that time already, ſhame
On my ſoule therefore.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you not ſee Sir, is your light ſo dim?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Do you not waite on the Lady Mount Marine?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do Sir, but my love on you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Poore ſoule! how cam'ſt thou by this big belly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: By heaven I ne're toucht your body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, unſweare that oath agen, I'le tell you all;
Theſe two yeares I have lov'd you, but the meanes
How to enjoy you, I did never know
Till twelfe night laſt, when hearing of your game
To take up wenches private in the night,
I apprehended ſtraight this courſe to make
My ſelfe as one of them, and waite your coming;
I did ſo, and enjoyed you, and now this child
That now is quicke within me: hide my ſhame,
And marry me: or elſe I muſt be forc't—

sp.speaker: Long within.
sp.l: Monſieur Bewford, Monſieur Bewford.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Whoſe that calls?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Are you a bed?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: No Sir, the hangings.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nay Mounſieur, I'le forbid that, we'le have faire play
Lend me your candle, are you taken Bewford?
A lecher of your practice, and cloſe carriage
To be diſcovered thus? I am a ſham'd
So great a Maſter in his art ſhould faile,
And ſtagger in his grounds.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Your wide,
This woman and my ſelfe are man and wife,
And have been ſo this halfe yeare,
Where are you now? have I been diſcovered?
You cannot breake ſo eaſily on me Sir,
I am to wary to be opend by you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But theſe are but illuſions to give couler
To your moſt miſticke leacherie, but Sir
The belly hath betray'd you all, it muſt out.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Good Longavile believe me on my faith,
I am her husband.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: On my faith I cannot unleſſe I ſaw
Your hands faſt and your heartes.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why Longavile when did I give that to your eares
That was not truth? by all the world ſhe's mine,
She is my wife and to confirme you better
I give my ſelfe againe, here take my hand
And I yours, we are once more married,
Will this content you?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Yes, I am believing, and God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: My loving wife I will not wrong thee,
Since I am thine and only loved of thee
From this houre I, vow my ſelfe a new man,
Be not jealous: for though I had a purpoſe,
To have ſpent an hower or two in ſolace otherwiſe,
And was provided for it, yet my love
Shall put a better temper to my blood,
Come out thou woman of unholſome life,
Be ſorry for thy ſinnes, and learne to mend,
Nay never hide your face, you ſhall be ſeene.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Jaques, why Jaques, art thou that Jaques,
The very ſtaffe, and right hand of our Duke?
Speake, thou bearded Venus.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am he, by miracle preſerv'd to be that Jaques,
Within this two houres Gentlemen, poore Jaques
Was but as coarſe in grave: a man of wiſedome,
That of my conſcience if he had his right
Should have a pretty ſtate, but that's all one
That noble Gentleman did ſave this life,
I keepe it for him, 'tis his owne.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Oh Bachus! is all the world drunke? come wee'le to the Duke
And give thankes for this delivery.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not gon unto my Tenants to relate
My grace and honour; and the mightyneſſe
Of my new name which would have ſtruck a terrour
Through their courſe doublets, to their very hearts?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Alas great Lord and Maſter, I could ſcarce
With ſafety of my life returne againe
Unto your graces houſe, and but for one
That had ſome mercie, I had ſure been hang'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My houſe?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes Sir, this houſe, your houſe 'ith towne.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques we are diſpleas'd, hath it no name?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What name?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dull rogue; what hath the King beſtowed
So many honours, open'd all his ſpringes,
And ſhowerd his graces downe upon my head,
And has my houſe no name? no title yet?
Burgundy houſe you Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your graces mercy,
And when I was come off, and had recover'd
Burgundy houſe, I durſt not yet be ſeene,
But lay all night for feare of purſuiuants
In Burgundy privie houſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O Sir, 'tis well,
Can you remember now? but Jaques know
Since thy intended journey is ſo croſte,
I will go downe my ſelfe this morning.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Have I not ſaid this morning?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But conſider,
That nothing is prepared yet for your journey,
Your graces teames not here to draw your cloathes;
And not a carrier yet in town to ſend by.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I ſay once more go about it,
You'r a wiſe man, you'de have m● linger time,
Till I have worne theſe cloathes out: will ye go?
Make ye ready wife. Exit. Jaques.

sp.speaker: Dutches.
sp.l: I am ſo, mighty Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay for the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: How? for the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes I am reſolv'd to ſee my Tenants in this bra|very
Make them a ſumptuous feaſt, with a ſlight ſhew,
Of Dives, and Lazarus, and a ſquib or two,
And ſo returne.

sp.speaker: Dutches.
sp.l: VVhy Sir? you are not mad?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How many Dukes have ye known mad? I pray ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You are the firſt Sir, and I hope the laſt,
But you are ſtark horne mad.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forbeare good wife.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: As I have faith you'r mad: your hornes
Have been to heavy for you, and have broke
Your skull in pieces: If you be in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: VVell you ſhall know my skull and wits are whole
Ere I have done, and yet I am in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Dutches.
sp.l: VVhy, do you think I'le go?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I ſhall? by what authority ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am your husband.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: True I confeſſe it,
And by that name the world hath given you
A power to ſway me; but Sir you ſhall know
There is a greater bond that tyes me here,
Alleagance to the King; has he not heapt
Thoſe honours on you to no other end,
But to ſtay you here, and ſhall I have a hand
In the offending ſuch a gracious Prince?
Beſides, our owne undoings lyes uppon't,
Were there no other cauſe, I do not ſee,
Why you ſhould go: If I ſhould ſay you ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Do you thinke ſo?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes faith.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now good wife make me underſtand that point.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Why that you ſhall, did I not bring you hither?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And were not all thoſe honours wrought out of the fire by me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: By you?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: By me; how ſtrang you make it?
When you came firſt did you not walke the Town,
In a long cloake halfe compaſſe? an old hat,
Linde with vellure, and on it for a band,
A skeine of crimſon cruell?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I confeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And tooke baſe courſes?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Baſe?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Baſe by this light, extreame baſe, and ſcurvie, monſtrous baſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What were theſe courſes, wife?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Why you ſhall know,
Did you not thus attired trot up and down,
Plotting for vild and lowſie offices,
And agreed with the Sergiant of the beares,
To buy his place? deny this if you can.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why it is true.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And was not that monſtrous baſe?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be advis'd wife, a beares a princly beaſt.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: A beare?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes wife, and one ſide venſon.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You'r more then one ſide foole, I'm ſure of that

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But ſince you have vext me wife, know you ſhall go
Nor you ſhall never have penny from me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nay I have done, and though I know 'twill be
Your overthrow, I'le not forſake you now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be ready then. Exit Duke.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What are you married Bewford?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: I as faſt as words, and hearts, and hands & Prieſt can make us.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: This Gentleman the Lord of lorne my husband,
Will be gon downe to ſhew his play fellowes,
Where he is gay.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: What, downe into the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes faith, was ever foole but he ſo croſſe?
I would as faine be gracious to him,
As he could wiſh me, but he will not let me;
Speake faithfully, will he deſerve my mercy?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: According to his merits he ſhould weare,
A guarded coate, and a great wooden dagger.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: If there be any woman that doth knowe,
The duties 'twixt a husband and his wife,
Will ſpeake but one word for him he ſhall ſcape;
Is not that reaſonable? but ther's none,
Be ready therefore, to purſue the plot
We had againſt a pinch, for he muſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: VVaite you here for him whilſt I go
And make the King acquainted with your ſport,
For feare he be incens'd for our attempting;
Places of ſo great honour. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Go, be ſpeedy.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Cozen, Wife, Jaques, Man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come let me ſee how all things are diſpoſed of.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: One Cart will ſerve for all your furniture,
With roome enough behinde to eaſe the footman
A capcaſe for your linnen, and your plate,
VVith a ſtrange locke that opens with Amen;
For my young Lord becauſe of eaſie portage,
A quiver of your graces linde with Cunney,
Made to be hang'd about the Nurſes neck,
Thus with a ſcarfe or towell.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis well, but had you ſtaid another weeke,
I would have had you, furniſht in ſuch pomp,
As never Duke of Burgundy was furniſht,
You ſhould have had a ſumpter though't had coſt me
The laying on my ſelfe: where now you are faine,
To hire a rippers mare, and buy new doſſers,
But I have got them painted with your armes,
VVith a faire darnex Carpet of my owne
Laid croſſe for the more ſtate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques I thanke you: your Carpet ſhall be bruſht
And ſent you home; what, are you ready wife?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: An houre agoe

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot chuſe but kiſſe thy royall lips,
Deare Dutches mine, thou art ſo good a woman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Yould ſay ſo if you knew all, goodman Duckling.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: This was the happieſt fortune could befall me
Now in his abſence will I follow cloſe
Mine owne preferment, and I hope e ere long,
To make my meane and humble name ſo ſtrong,
As my great Couzens, when the world ſhall know,
I beare too hot a ſpirit to live low
The next Spring wil I down my wife and houſhold,
I'le have My Uſhers, and my foure Lacquies,
Six ſpare croches too: but mum, no more,
What I intend to do, I'le keep in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Mountye, mountye, Iaques, be our querry.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: To horſe there Gentlemen, and fall in couples.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come honoured Ducheſſe. Enter Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Stand thou proud man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thieves, Iaques, raiſe the people.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, raiſe no people, 'tis the Kings command,
Which bids thee once more ſtand thou haughty man,
Thou art a monſter, for thou art ungratefull,
And like a fellow of a rebell nature,
Haſt flung from his embraces: and for
His honours given thee, haſt not returnd
So much as thanks, and to oppoſe his will,
Reſolv'd to leave the Court, and ſet the Realm
A fire, in diſcontent, and open action:
Therefore he bids thee ſtand thou proud man,
Whilſt with the whisking of my ſword about
I take thy honours off: this firſt ſad whiske
Takes off thy Duke-dome, thou art but an Earl.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are miſtaken, Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O would I were, this ſecond whiske divides
Thy Earldome from thee, thou art yet a Baron.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No more whisks if you love me Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Two whisks are paſt, and two are yet behind,
Yet all muſt come, but not to linger time.
With theſe two whisks I end, now Mount Marine,
For thou art now no more, ſo ſays the King,
And I have done his Highneſſe will with griefe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Diſgraced from my honours?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: 'Tis too certaine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am no Traitor ſure that I know of;
Speak Iaques? haſt thou ever heard me utter word
Tending to treaſon, or to bring in the enemy?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Alas ſir I know nothing,
Why ſhould your Worſhip bring me in to hang me?
God's my judge Gentlemen I never medled
But with the bruſhing of his cloaths, or fetching
In water in a morning for his hands.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Are theſe the honours of this place? Antony
Help me to take her gowne off quickly
Or I'le ſo ſwinge ye for't—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why husband? Sir?

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: I'le not looſe a penny by this towne.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Why what do you meane ſir, have her to her lodging,
And there undreſſe her, I will waite upon her.

sp.speaker: Couſ.
sp.l: Indeed you ſhall not, your moneth is out I take it,
Get you out before me wife:
Couzen farewell, I told you long agoe,
That pride begins with pleaſure, ends with woe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Goe thy way ſentences, 'twill be thy fortune,
To live and dye a Cuckold and Church-warden.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: O my poor husband! what a heavy fortune
Is fallen upon him?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Me thinks 'tis ſtrange,
That heaven fore-warning great men of their falls,
With ſuch plaine tokens, they ſhould not avoid them?
For the laſt night betwixt eleven and twelve,
Two great and hideous blazing ſtars were ſeen
To fight a long houre by the clocke, the one
Dreſt like a Duke, the other like a King,
Till at the laſt the crowned ſtar ore-came.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why do ye ſtand ſo dead, Monſieur Marine?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So Caeſar fell when in the Capitoll
They gave his body two and thirty wounds.
Be warned all ye Peers, and by my fall,
Hereafter learn to let your wives rule all.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Monſieur Marine, pray let me speak with you;
Sir I muſt wave you to conceale this party,
It ſtands upon my utter overthrow;
Seem not diſcontented, nor do not ſtir a foote,
For if you do, you and your hope—
I ſweare you are a loſt man if you ſtir.
And have an eye to Bewford, he'l tempt you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Come, come, for ſhame goe downe;
Were I Marine, by heaven I would goe down:
And being there, I would rattle him ſuch an anſwer
Should make him ſmoake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Good Monſieur Bewford peace
Leave theſe rebellious words,
Or by the honours which I once enjoyed,
And yet may ſweare by,
I'le tell the King of your proceedings;
I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You talkt of going down when 'twas not fit,
But now let's ſee your ſpirit,
A thouſand and a thouſand will expect it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why wife, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No nor drunk, but I'de have you know your own ſtrength

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You talk like a moſt fooliſh woman wife;
I tell you I will ſtay, yet I have a
Cratchet troubles me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: More cratchets yet?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Follow me Jaq. I muſt have thy counſell,
I will returne againe, ſtay you there Wife.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I fear this loſſe of honour will give him ſome few ſtooles.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, he is reſolv'd, he will not
Stir a foote I'le lay my life.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I but hee's diſcontented, how ſhall we reſolve that
And make him ſtay with comfort?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Faith Bewford we muſt even let nature work,
For hee's the ſweeteſt temper'd man for that
As one can wiſh, for let men but goe about to foole him,
And hee'l have his finger as deep in 't as the beſt;
But ſee where he comes frowning, bleſſe us all!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Off with your hats, for here doth come
The high and mighty Duke of Burgundy.
What ever you may think, I have thought
And thought, and thought upon't, and I finde it plaine,
The King cannot take backe what he has given,
Unleſſe I forfeit it by courſe of Law.
Not all the water in the river Sene,
Can waſh the blood out of theſe Princely veines.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God a mercy husband, thou art the beſt
To worke out a thing at a pinch, in France.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I will aſcend my ſtate againe,
Ducheſſe take your place,
And let our Champion enter.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Has he his Champion? that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And let loud muſick ſound before his entrance.
Sound Trumpet.

div.stage: Enter Iaques in armour, one carrying a Scuchion before him, and a two-handed ſword.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How well our Champion doth demean himſelfe,
As if he had been made for ſuch an action?
Me thinks his ſturdy trunchion he doth wield,
Like Mars approaching to a bloody field.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think ther's no man ſo deſperate
To dare encounter with our Champion,
But truſt me, Iaques, thou haſt pleas'd us well;
Once more our warlike muſick, then proceed. En: Shat.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: What wondrous age is this? what cloſe proceedings?
I heare the clang of Trumpets in this houſe,
To what intent do not our States-men ſearch?
O no, they look not into ſimple truth;
For I am true, and they regard not me,
A man in armour too: God ſave the King
The world will end, theres nought but treachery.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I Ja. ſervant to the high & mighty Godfrey Duke of Burgundy, do come hither to prove by natural ſtrength and activity of my body, without the help of ſorcery, inchant||ment, or negromancy, that the ſaid Godfrey late of Mount Marine, & now of Burgundy, hath perfect right therto, not|withſtanding the Kings command to the contrary, & no other perſon whatſoever: & in token that I wilbe ready to make good the ſame: I throw down my gage, w^c^h is my ho|nour, pronounced the 37. of Feb. ſtilo novo, God ſave the D.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Of all the plots the King hath laid for me
This was the ſhrewdeſt, 'tis my life they ſeeke,
And they ſhall have it: if I ſhould refuſe
To accept the challenge in the Kings behalfe,
They have ſome cauſe to take away my life,
And if I do accept it, who can tell,
But I may fall by doubtfull chance of war?
'Twas ſhrewd, but I muſt take the leaſt of evills,
I take thy gauntlet up thou treacherous man,
That ſtands in armed coate againſt the King,
Whom God preſerve, and with my ſingle ſword
Will juſtifie whatever he commands;
I'le watch him for catching of my words.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques goe on, defend our Princely title.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why ſhrinkſt thou backe? thou haſt an evill cauſe;
Come forward man, I have a rocke about me,
I fight for my true Liege.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Goe forward Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do beeſeech your Grace to pardon me,
I will not fight with him, with any elſe
I'le ſhew my reſolution ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Come do thy worſt, for the King ſhall ſee
All is not true that is reported of me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I may not fight with him by law of armes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What? ſhall my title fall? wilt thou not fight?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Never with him that once hath ſav'd my life.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou not fight? behold then I doe goe
Strong with the zeale I beare my Soveraign,
And ſeize upon that haughty man himſelfe.
Deſcend the ſteps that (thou haſt thus uſurpt
Againſt the King and State) downe to the ground,
And if thou doe utter but a ſyllable
To croſſe the Kings intent, thou art but dead;
There, lye upon the earth and pine and dye.
Did ever any man wade through ſuch ſtormes,
To ſave his life, as poore Shattillion?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I feare this challenge hath ſpoil'd all.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Ne're feare it, hee'l work it out againe ſervant.
See where Shattillions Love, poor Lady, comes. En: Love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Lye ſtill ſir if you love your life, I'le whiſtle when he's gone,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, I charge you by the love
Which you beare to women, take ſome pitty
On this diſtreſſed man, help to reſtore
That pretious jewell to him he hath loſt.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Lady what ever power doth lye in us
By art or prayer, or danger, we are yours,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A ſtrange conceite hath wrought this malady,
Conceites againe muſt bring him to himſelfe,
My ſtrict denyall to his will wrought this?
And if you could but draw his wilder thoughts
To know me, he would ſure recover ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: That charge I'le undertake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Looke Jaques, look, for Gods ſake let me riſe,
This greatneſſe is a Jade, I cannot ſit it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: His ſword is up, and yet he watcheth you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'le down again, pray for thy Maſter, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Now the King may ſee all the ſuggeſtions are not true,
He hath receiv'd againſt my loyalty;
When all men elſe refuſe, I fight his battails,
And thruſt my body into dangers mouth;
I am become his Champion, and this ſword
Has taught his enemies to know themſelves;
O that he would no more be jealous of me!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Monſieur Shattillion, the King aſſigns you,
That for this valiant loyall act of yours,
He hath forgot all jealouſies and feares,
And never more will tempt you into danger.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But how ſhall I believe this? what new token
Of reconcilement will he ſhew me?
Let him releaſe my poor love from her torment,
From her hard fare and ſtrict impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He hath done this to win your after-love,
And ſee your Lady ſent you from the King
By theſe two Gentlemen: be thankfull for her.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: She lives, ſhe lives, I know her by the power
Shoots from her eyes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Riſe deare Sbattillion.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I Know my duty,
Next unto my King, I am to kneele to you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'le have you riſe, fetch me a chair, ſit down Shat.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am commanded, and faith tell me Miſtris,
What uſage have you had? pray be plaine?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O my moſt lov'd Shattillion, paine enough,
But now I am free, thanks to my God and King.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: His eyes grow very heavy, not a word,
That his weak ſenſes may come ſweetly home.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: The King is honourable.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When do you whiſtle Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: By and by.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Come hither Monſieur, canſt thou laugh a little?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So thou ſhalt then. Bewford how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why well.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'me glad on't, and how does thy wife?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why you may ſee her Sir, ſhe ſtands behind you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: By the maſs ſhe's there indeed, but wher's her belly?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Belly?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Her great belly man: what haſt thou ſent thee?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: A boy I'le lay my life, it tumbled ſo.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Catcht by this light.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'le be a goſſip Bewford.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I have an odd Apoſtle ſpoone.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: S' foote catcht.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Why what's the matter Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He's married to your woman.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: And I not know it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: 'Twas a veniall ſin.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Gall, gall, gall.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Forgive her Monſieur Bewford, 'twas her love.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You may riſe if you pleaſe, I muſt endure it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: See how my great Lord lyes upon the ground
And dare not ſtir yet?
Jaques, whiſtles?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques, Jaq. is the Kings Champion gone yet,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No, but hee's aſleep.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is he aſleep art ſure?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I am ſure he is, I heare him ſnore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then by your favours Gentlemen I riſe,
And know I am a Duke ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And I am his Champion.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Hold thee there, and all France cannot mend thee.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am a Prince as great within my thoughts
As when the whole ſtate did adorn my perſon;
What tryall can be made to try a Prince?
I will oppoſe this noble corps of mine
To any danger that may end the doubt.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Great Duke and husband there is but one way
To ſatisfie the world of our true right,
And it is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What may it be?
Were it to bring the great Turke bound in chaines
Through France in triumph: or to couple up
The Sophie, and great Preſter Iohn together,
I would attempt it Ducheſſe, tell the courſe.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: There is a ſtrong opinion through the world,
And no doubt grounded on experience
That Lyons will not touch a lawfull Prince,
If you be confident then of your right,
Amongſt the Lions beare your naked body,
And if you come off cleare and never winch,
The world will ſay you are a perfect Prince.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you Ducheſſe for your kinde advice,
But now we do not affect thoſe ravenous beaſts.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: A Lyon is a beaſt to try a King;
But for the triall of ſuch a ſtate like this
Pliny reports a maſtive dog will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We will not deale with dogs at all: but men.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You ſhall not need to deale with them at all,
Hark you Sir, the King doth know you are a Duke:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, does he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes, and is content you ſhall be, but with this caution,
That none know it but your ſelfe:
For if ye do, he'l take it away by act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here's my hand, and whilſt I live or breath,
No living wight ſhall know I am a Duke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Marke me directly Sir, your wife may know it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May not Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes, he may.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May not my countrey Couzen?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: By no meanes ſir, if you love your life and ſtate.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well then, know all I am no Duke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No I'le ſweare it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: See he wakes.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Where am I, or where have I been all this while?
Sleep hath not ſate ſo ſound upon mine eyes
But I remember well that face;
O thou too cruell, leave at length to ſcorne
Him that but looking on thy beauty dyes,
Either receive me, or put out my eyes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Deareſt Shattillion ſee upon my knees,
I offer up my love, forget my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Art thou mine own?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: By heaven I am.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then all the world is mine.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I have ſtranger things to tel thee, my deareſt love.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Tell nothing but that thou art mine own:
I do not care to know where I have been,
Or how I have liv'd, or any thing,
But that thou art my own.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Well wife, though 'twere a trick that made us wed,
Wee'l make our ſelves merry ſoone in bed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Know all I am no Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What ſaye?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am a Duke.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Are yee?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes faith, yes faith.
But it muſt only run amongſt our ſelves,
And Jaques thou ſhalt be my Secretary ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Kinde Gentlemen, leade in Shattillion,
For he muſt needs be weak and ſickly yet.
Now all my labours have a perfect end as I could wiſh,
Let all young ſprightly wives that have
Dull fooliſh Coxcombs to their husbands,
Learn by me their duties, what to doe,
VVhich is to make 'em fooles, and pleaſe 'em too.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: WIt is become an anticke: and puts on
To court the times applauſe, as the times dare,
Change ſeverall faſhions, nothing is thought rare
Which is not new and follow'd, yet we know,
That what was worne ſome twenty yeare agoe,
Comes into grace againe, and we purſue
That cuſtome, by preſenting to your view
A play in faſhion then, not doubting now
But 'twill appeare the ſame, if you allow
Worth to their noble memory, whoſe name,
Beyond all power of death live in their fame.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: THe Monuments of vertue and deſert,
Appeare more goodly when the gloſſe of art
Is eaten off by time, then when at firſt
They were ſet up, not cenſur'd at the worſt.
We have done our beſt for your contents to fit
With new paines this old monument of wit.
